Quote: These levels designate fine-grained informational events that are most useful to debug an application.
Verbose is the noisiest level, rarely (if ever) enabled for a production app.
A fine-grained debug message, typically capturing the flow through the application
The TRACE Level designates finer-grained informational events than the DEBUG level.
more detailed information. Expect these to be written to logs only.
Logging from external libraries used by your app or very detailed application logging.
The Trace level designates fine-grained informational events that are most useful to debug an application.
Logs that contain the most detailed messages. These messages may contain sensitive application data. These messages are disabled by default and should never be enabled in a production environment
Finest-grained informational events.
Designates finer-grained informational events than the Debug.
Writes a trace message to the log.
"Houston, we have a %s", "thorny problem"
Designates lower priority information
A general debugging event
The DEBUG Level designates fine-grained informational events that are most useful to debug an application.
Detailed information on the flow through the system. Expect these to be written to logs only.
Anything else, i. e. too verbose to bee included in "info" level
Debug-level messages / The message is only for debugging purposes
The Debug level designates fine-grained informational events that are most useful to debug an application.

Logs that are used for interactive investigation during development.
These logs should primarily contain information useful for debugging
and have no long-term value
Debug is used for internal system events that are not necessarily observable from the outside, but useful when determining how something happened
Detailed debug information
Fine-grained informational events that are most useful to debug an application.
DebugLevel level. Usually only enabled when debugging. Very verbose logging.
DebugLevel logs are typically voluminous, and are usually disabled in production.
Low-level information for developers.
Captures verbose information during development that is useful only for debugging your code.
"Houston, we have a %s", "interesting problem"
Designates useful information
An event for informational purposes
The INFO level designates informational messages that highlight the progress of the application at coarse-grained level.
Interesting runtime events (startup/shutdown). Expect these to be immediately visible on a console, so be conservative and keep to a minimum.
Detail on regular operation.
Informational messages / The message is purely informational
The Info level designates informational messages that highlight the progress of the application at coarse-grained level.
Logs that track the general flow of the application. These logs should have long-term value.
Information events describe things happening in the system that correspond to its responsibilities and functions. Generally these are the observable actions the system can perform.
Interesting events
Informational messages that highlight the progress of the application at coarse-grained level.
General operational entries about what's going on inside the application.
InfoLevel is the default logging priority.
Generic (useful) information about system operation.
Captures information that is helpful, but not essential, to troubleshoot problems.
Normal but significant condition / The message describes a normal but important event
The Notice level designates informational messages that highlight the progress of the application at the highest level.
Uncommon events
Captures information that is essential for troubleshooting problems. For example, capture information that might result in a failure.
"Houston, we have a %s", "bit of a problem"
Designates hazardous situations.
An event that might possible lead to an error
The WARN level designates potentially harmful situations.

Use of deprecated APIs, poor use of API, 'almost' errors, other runtime situations that are undesirable or unexpected, but not necessarily "wrong". Expect these to be immediately visible on a status console.
A note on something that should probably be looked at by an operator eventually.

Logs that highlight an abnormal or unexpected event in the application
flow, but do not otherwise cause the application execution to stop.
Exceptional occurrences that are not errors
Potentially harmful situations which still allow the application to continue running.
Non-critical entries that deserve eyes.
WarnLevel logs are more important than Info, but don't need individual human review.
A warning.
Writes information about a warning to the log.
"Houston, we have a %s", "major problem"
Designates very serious errors
An error in the application, possibly recoverable
The ERROR level designates error events that might still allow the application to continue running.
Other runtime errors or unexpected conditions. Expect these to be immediately visible on a status console.
Fatal for a particular request, but the service/app continues servicing other requests. An operator should look at this soon(ish).
Error conditions / The message describes an error
The Error level designates error events that might still allow the application to continue running.
Logs that highlight when the current flow of execution is stopped due to a failure. These should indicate a failure in the current activity, not an application-wide failure
Runtime errors
Error events that might still allow the application to continue running.
Used for errors that should definitely be noted.
ErrorLevel logs are high-priority. If an application is running smoothly, it shouldn't generate any error-level logs.
A handleable error condition.
Captures errors seen during the execution of your code. If an activity object exists, the system captures information for the related process chain.
Captures information about faults and bugs in your code. If an activity object exists, the system captures information for the related process chain.
The Severe level designates very severe error events.
"Houston, we have a %s", "major disaster"
Critical conditions / The message states a critical condition
The Critical level designates very severe error events. Critical condition, critical.
Logs that describe an unrecoverable application or system crash, or a catastrophic failure that requires immediate attention
Critical conditions
Action must be taken immediately / Action on the message must be taken imediately
The Alert level designates very severe error events. Take immediate action, alerts.
Action must be taken immediately
A severe error that will prevent the application from continuing
The FATAL level designates very severe error events that will presumably lead the application to abort.
Severe errors that cause premature termination. Expect these to be immediately visible on a status console.
The service/app is going to stop or become unusable now. An operator should definitely look into this soon.
The Fatal level designates very severe error events that will presumably lead the application to abort.
Very severe error events that will presumably lead the application to abort.
Logs and then calls `logger.Exit(1)`. It will exit even if the logging level is set to Panic.
FatalLevel logs a message, then calls os.Exit(1).
An unhandleable error that results in a program crash.
System is unusable / The message says the system is unusable
The Emergency level designates very severe error events. System unusable, emergencies.
Urgent alert
